55 /*
56 * jmorecfg.h
57 *
58 * Copyright (C) 1991-1997, Thomas G. Lane.
59 * This file is part of the Independent JPEG Group's software.
60 * For conditions of distribution and use, see the accompanying README file.
61 *
62 * This file contains additional configuration options that customize the
63 * JPEG software for special applications or support machine-dependent
64 * optimizations. Most users will not need to touch this file.
65 */
66
67#include "algo.h"
68
69/*
70 * Define BITS_IN_JSAMPLE as either
71 * 8 for 8-bit sample values (the usual setting)
72 * 12 for 12-bit sample values
73 * Only 8 and 12 are legal data precisions for lossy JPEG according to the
74 * JPEG standard, and the IJG code does not support anything else!
75 * We do not support run-time selection of data precision, sorry.
76 */
77
78#define BITS_IN_JSAMPLE 8 /* use 8 or 12 */
79
80/*
81 * Maximum number of components (color channels) allowed in JPEG image.
82 * To meet the letter of the JPEG spec, set this to 255. However, darn
83 * few applications need more than 4 channels (maybe 5 for CMYK + alpha
84 * mask). We recommend 10 as a reasonable compromise; use 4 if you are
85 * really short on memory. (Each allowed component costs a hundred or so
86 * bytes of storage, whether actually used in an image or not.)
87 */
88
89#define MAX_COMPONENTS 10 /* maximum number of image components */
90
91/*
92 * Basic data types.
93 * You may need to change these if you have a machine with unusual data
94 * type sizes; for example, "char" not 8 bits, "short" not 16 bits,
95 * or "long" not 32 bits. We don't care whether "int" is 16 or 32 bits,
96 * but it had better be at least 16.
97 */
98
99/* Representation of a single sample (pixel element value).
100 * We frequently allocate large arrays of these, so it's important to keep
101 * them small. But if you have memory to burn and access to char or short
102 * arrays is very slow on your hardware, you might want to change these.
103 */
104
105#if BITS_IN_JSAMPLE == 8
106/* JSAMPLE should be the smallest type that will hold the values 0..255.
107 * You can use a signed char by having GETJSAMPLE mask it with 0xFF.
108 */
109
110#ifdef HAVE_UNSIGNED_CHAR
111
112typedef unsigned char JSAMPLE;
113#define GETJSAMPLE(value) ((int) (value))
114
115#else /* not HAVE_UNSIGNED_CHAR */
116
117typedef char JSAMPLE;
118#ifdef CHAR_IS_UNSIGNED
119#define GETJSAMPLE(value) ((int) (value))
120#else
121#define GETJSAMPLE(value) ((int) (value) & 0xFF)
122#endif /* CHAR_IS_UNSIGNED */
123
124#endif /* HAVE_UNSIGNED_CHAR */
125
126#define MAXJSAMPLE 255
127#define CENTERJSAMPLE 128
128
129#endif /* BITS_IN_JSAMPLE == 8 */
130
131#if BITS_IN_JSAMPLE == 12
132/* JSAMPLE should be the smallest type that will hold the values 0..4095.
133 * On nearly all machines "short" will do nicely.
134 */
135
136typedef short JSAMPLE;
137#define GETJSAMPLE(value) ((int) (value))
138
139#define MAXJSAMPLE 4095
140#define CENTERJSAMPLE 2048
141
142#endif /* BITS_IN_JSAMPLE == 12 */
143
144/* Representation of a DCT frequency coefficient.
145 * This should be a signed value of at least 16 bits; "short" is usually OK.
146 * Again, we allocate large arrays of these, but you can change to int
147 * if you have memory to burn and "short" is really slow.
148 */
149
150typedef short JCOEF;
151
152/* Compressed datastreams are represented as arrays of JOCTET.
153 * These must be EXACTLY 8 bits wide, at least once they are written to
154 * external storage. Note that when using the stdio data source/destination
155 * managers, this is also the data type passed to fread/fwrite.
156 */
157
158#ifdef HAVE_UNSIGNED_CHAR
159
160typedef unsigned char JOCTET;
161#define GETJOCTET(value) (value)
162
163#else /* not HAVE_UNSIGNED_CHAR */
164
165typedef char JOCTET;
166#ifdef CHAR_IS_UNSIGNED
167#define GETJOCTET(value) (value)
168#else
169#define GETJOCTET(value) ((value) & 0xFF)
170#endif /* CHAR_IS_UNSIGNED */
171
172#endif /* HAVE_UNSIGNED_CHAR */
173
174/* These typedefs are used for various table entries and so forth.
175 * They must be at least as wide as specified; but making them too big
176 * won't cost a huge amount of memory, so we don't provide special
177 * extraction code like we did for JSAMPLE. (In other words, these
178 * typedefs live at a different point on the speed/space tradeoff curve.)
179 */
180
181/* e_u8 must hold at least the values 0..255. */
182/* e_u16 must hold at least the values 0..65535. */
183/* e_s16 must hold at least the values -32768..32767. */
184/* e_s32 must hold at least signed 32-bit values. */
185
186/* Datatype used for image dimensions. The JPEG standard only supports
187 * images up to 64K*64K due to 16-bit fields in SOF markers. Therefore
188 * "unsigned int" is sufficient on all machines. However, if you need to
189 * handle larger images and you don't mind deviating from the spec, you
190 * can change this datatype.
191 */
192
193typedef unsigned int JDIMENSION;
194
195#define JPEG_MAX_DIMENSION 65500L /* a tad under 64K to prevent overflows */
196
197/* These macros are used in all function definitions and extern declarations.
198 * You could modify them if you need to change function linkage conventions;
199 * in particular, you'll need to do that to make the library a Windows DLL.
200 * Another application is to make all functions global for use with debuggers
201 * or code profilers that require it.
202 */
203
204/* a function called through method pointers: */
205#define METHODDEF(type) static type
206/* a function used only in its module: */
207#define LOCAL(type) static type
208/* a function referenced thru EXTERNs: */
209#define GLOBAL(type) type
210/* a reference to a GLOBAL function: */
211#define EXTERN(type) extern type
212
213/* This macro is used to declare a "method", that is, a function pointer.
214 * We want to supply prototype parameters if the compiler can cope.
215 * Note that the arglist parameter must be parenthesized!
216 * Again, you can customize this if you need special linkage keywords.
217 */
218
219#ifdef HAVE_PROTOTYPES
220#define JMETHOD(type,methodname,arglist) type (*methodname) arglist
221#else
222#define JMETHOD(type,methodname,arglist) type (*methodname) ()
223#endif
224
225/*
226 * On a few systems, type boolean and/or its values FALSE, TRUE may appear
227 * in standard header files. Or you may have conflicts with application-
228 * specific header files that you want to include together with these files.
229 * Defining HAVE_BOOLEAN before including jpeglib.h should make it work.
230 */
231
232#ifndef HAVE_BOOLEAN
233typedef unsigned char boolean;
234#endif
235
236/*
237 * The remaining options affect code selection within the JPEG library,
238 * but they don't need to be visible to most applications using the library.
239 * To minimize application namespace pollution, the symbols won't be
240 * defined unless JPEG_INTERNALS or JPEG_INTERNAL_OPTIONS has been defined.
241 */
242
243#ifdef JPEG_INTERNALS
244#define JPEG_INTERNAL_OPTIONS
245#endif
246
247#ifdef JPEG_INTERNAL_OPTIONS
248
249/*
250 * These defines indicate whether to include various optional functions.
251 * Undefining some of these symbols will produce a smaller but less capable
252 * library. Note that you can leave certain source files out of the
253 * compilation/linking process if you've #undef'd the corresponding symbols.
254 * (You may HAVE to do that if your compiler doesn't like null source files.)
255 */
256
257/* Arithmetic coding is unsupported for legal reasons. Complaints to IBM. */
258
259/* Capability options common to encoder and decoder: */
260
261#define DCT_ISLOW_SUPPORTED /* slow but accurate integer algorithm */
262#undef DCT_IFAST_SUPPORTED /* faster, less accurate integer method */
263#undef DCT_FLOAT_SUPPORTED /* floating-point: accurate, fast on fast HW */
264
265/* Encoder capability options: */
266
267#undef C_ARITH_CODING_SUPPORTED /* Arithmetic coding back end? */
268#define C_MULTISCAN_FILES_SUPPORTED /* Multiple-scan JPEG files? */
269#define C_PROGRESSIVE_SUPPORTED /* Progressive JPEG? (Requires MULTISCAN)*/
270#define ENTROPY_OPT_SUPPORTED /* Optimization of entropy coding parms? */
271/* Note: if you selected 12-bit data precision, it is dangerous to turn off
272 * ENTROPY_OPT_SUPPORTED. The standard Huffman tables are only good for 8-bit
273 * precision, so jchuff.c normally uses entropy optimization to compute
274 * usable tables for higher precision. If you don't want to do optimization,
275 * you'll have to supply different default Huffman tables.
276 * The exact same statements apply for progressive JPEG: the default tables
277 * don't work for progressive mode. (This may get fixed, however.)
278 */
279#define INPUT_SMOOTHING_SUPPORTED /* Input image smoothing option? */
280
281/* Decoder capability options: */
282
283#undef D_ARITH_CODING_SUPPORTED /* Arithmetic coding back end? */
284#define D_MULTISCAN_FILES_SUPPORTED /* Multiple-scan JPEG files? */
285#define D_PROGRESSIVE_SUPPORTED /* Progressive JPEG? (Requires MULTISCAN)*/
286#define SAVE_MARKERS_SUPPORTED /* jpeg_save_markers() needed? */
287#define BLOCK_SMOOTHING_SUPPORTED /* Block smoothing? (Progressive only) */
288#define IDCT_SCALING_SUPPORTED /* Output rescaling via IDCT? */
289#undef UPSAMPLE_SCALING_SUPPORTED /* Output rescaling at upsample stage? */
290#define UPSAMPLE_MERGING_SUPPORTED /* Fast path for sloppy upsampling? */
291#define QUANT_1PASS_SUPPORTED /* 1-pass color quantization? */
292#define QUANT_2PASS_SUPPORTED /* 2-pass color quantization? */
293
294/* more capability options later, no doubt */
295
296/*
297 * Ordering of RGB data in scanlines passed to or from the application.
298 * If your application wants to deal with data in the order B,G,R, just
299 * change these macros. You can also deal with formats such as R,G,B,X
300 * (one extra byte per pixel) by changing RGB_PIXELSIZE. Note that changing
301 * the offsets will also change the order in which colormap data is organized.
302 * RESTRICTIONS:
303 * 1. The sample applications cjpeg,djpeg do NOT support modified RGB formats.
304 * 2. These macros only affect RGB<=>YCbCr color conversion, so they are not
305 * useful if you are using JPEG color spaces other than YCbCr or grayscale.
306 * 3. The color quantizer modules will not behave desirably if RGB_PIXELSIZE
307 * is not 3 (they don't understand about dummy color components!). So you
308 * can't use color quantization if you change that value.
309 */
310
311#define RGB_RED 0 /* Offset of Red in an RGB scanline element */
312#define RGB_GREEN 1 /* Offset of Green */
313#define RGB_BLUE 2 /* Offset of Blue */
314#define RGB_PIXELSIZE 3 /* JSAMPLEs per RGB scanline element */
315
316/* Definitions for speed-related optimizations. */
317
318/* If your compiler supports inline functions, define INLINE
319 * as the inline keyword; otherwise define it as empty.
320 */
321
322#ifndef INLINE
323#ifdef __GNUC__ /* for instance, GNU C knows about inline */
324#define INLINE __inline__
325#endif
326#ifndef INLINE
327#define INLINE /* default is to define it as empty */
328#endif
329#endif
330
331/* On some machines (notably 68000 series) "int" is 32 bits, but multiplying
332 * two 16-bit shorts is faster than multiplying two ints. Define MULTIPLIER
333 * as short on such a machine. MULTIPLIER must be at least 16 bits wide.
334 */
335
336#ifndef MULTIPLIER
337#define MULTIPLIER int /* type for fastest integer multiply */
338#endif
339
340/* FAST_FLOAT should be either float or double, whichever is done faster
341 * by your compiler. (Note that this type is only used in the floating point
342 * DCT routines, so it only matters if you've defined DCT_FLOAT_SUPPORTED.)
343 * Typically, float is faster in ANSI C compilers, while double is faster in
344 * pre-ANSI compilers (because they insist on converting to double anyway).
345 * The code below therefore chooses float if we have ANSI-style prototypes.
346 */
347
348#ifndef FAST_FLOAT
349#ifdef HAVE_PROTOTYPES
350#define FAST_FLOAT float
351#else
352#define FAST_FLOAT double
353#endif
354#endif
355
356#endif /* JPEG_INTERNAL_OPTIONS */
